speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: SCENE I. Before LEONATO'S house.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Enter LEONATO and ANTONIO

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: If you go on thus, you will kill yourself:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And 'tis not wisdom thus to second grief

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Against yourself.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I pray thee, cease thy counsel,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Which falls into mine ears as profitless

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: As water in a sieve: give not me counsel;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Nor let no comforter delight mine ear

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Bring me a father that so loved his child,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Whose joy of her is overwhelm'd like mine,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And bid him speak of patience;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And let it answer every strain for strain,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: As thus for thus and such a grief for such,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: In every lineament, branch, shape, and form:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: If such a one will smile and stroke his beard,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Bid sorrow wag, cry 'hem!' when he should groan,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: With candle-wasters; bring him yet to me,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And I of him will gather patience.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: But there is no such man: for, brother, men

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Which they themselves not feel; but, tasting it,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Their counsel turns to passion, which before

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Would give preceptial medicine to rage,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Fetter strong madness in a silken thread,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Charm ache with air and agony with words:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: No, no; 'tis all men's office to speak patience

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To those that wring under the load of sorrow,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: But no man's virtue nor sufficiency

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To be so moral when he shall endure

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My griefs cry louder than advertisement.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I pray thee, peace. I will be flesh and blood;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: For there was never yet philosopher

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: That could endure the toothache patiently,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: However they have writ the style of gods

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And made a push at chance and sufferance.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Make those that do offend you suffer too.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: There thou speak'st reason: nay, I will do so.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My soul doth tell me Hero is belied;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And that shall Claudio know; so shall the prince

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And all of them that thus dishonour her.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Here comes the prince and Claudio hastily.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Enter DON PEDRO and CLAUDIO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Good den, good den.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Good day to both of you.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Hear you. my lords,--

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: We have some haste, Leonato.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Some haste, my lord! well, fare you well, my lord:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Are you so hasty now? well, all is one.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: If he could right himself with quarreling,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Some of us would lie low.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Who wrongs him?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Marry, thou dost wrong me; thou dissembler, thou:--

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I fear thee not.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Marry, beshrew my hand,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If it should give your age such cause of fear:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Tush, tush, man; never fleer and jest at me:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I speak not like a dotard nor a fool,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: As under privilege of age to brag

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: What I have done being young, or what would do

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Were I not old. Know, Claudio, to thy head,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Thou hast so wrong'd mine innocent child and me

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: That I am forced to lay my reverence by

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And, with grey hairs and bruise of many days,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Do challenge thee to trial of a man.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I say thou hast belied mine innocent child;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And she lies buried with her ancestors;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O, in a tomb where never scandal slept,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Save this of hers, framed by thy villany!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: My villany?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Thine, Claudio; thine, I say.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: You say not right, old man.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My lord, my lord,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I'll prove it on his body, if he dare,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Despite his nice fence and his active practise,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Away! I will not have to do with you.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Canst thou so daff me? Thou hast kill'd my child:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: If thou kill'st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: But that's no matter; let him kill one first;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Win me and wear me; let him answer me.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Come, follow me, boy; come, sir boy, come, follow me:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Sir boy, I'll whip you from your foining fence;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Brother,--

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Content yourself. God knows I loved my niece;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And she is dead, slander'd to death by villains,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: That dare as well answer a man indeed

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: As I dare take a serpent by the tongue:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Boys, apes, braggarts, Jacks, milksops!

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Brother Antony,--

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Hold you content. What, man! I know them, yea,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple,--

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Scrambling, out-facing, fashion-monging boys,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Go anticly, show outward hideousness,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And speak off half a dozen dangerous words,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And this is all.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: But, brother Antony,--

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Come, 'tis no matter:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Do not you meddle; let me deal in this.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: My heart is sorry for your daughter's death:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: But, on my honour, she was charged with nothing

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: But what was true and very full of proof.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My lord, my lord,--

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I will not hear you.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: No? Come, brother; away! I will be heard.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And shall, or some of us will smart for it.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Exeunt LEONATO and ANTONIO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: See, see; here comes the man we went to seek.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Enter BENEDICK

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Now, signior, what news?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Good day, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Welcome, signior: you are almost come to part

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: almost a fray.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: We had like to have had our two noses snapped off

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: with two old men without teeth.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Leonato and his brother. What thinkest thou? Had

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: we fought, I doubt we should have been too young for them.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: In a false quarrel there is no true valour. I came

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to seek you both.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: We have been up and down to seek thee; for we are

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: high-proof melancholy and would fain have it beaten

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: away. Wilt thou use thy wit?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: It is in my scabbard: shall I draw it?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Dost thou wear thy wit by thy side?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Never any did so, though very many have been beside

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: their wit. I will bid thee draw, as we do the

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: minstrels; draw, to pleasure us.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: As I am an honest man, he looks pale. Art thou

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: sick, or angry?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: What, courage, man! What though care killed a cat,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, and you

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: charge it against me. I pray you choose another subject.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Nay, then, give him another staff: this last was

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: broke cross.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: By this light, he changes more and more: I think

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: he be angry indeed.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Shall I speak a word in your ear?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: God bless me from a challenge!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: [Aside to CLAUDIO]  You are a villain; I jest not:

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I will make it good how you dare, with what you

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: dare, and when you dare. Do me right, or I will

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: protest your cowardice. You have killed a sweet

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: lady, and her death shall fall heavy on you. Let me

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: hear from you.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Well, I will meet you, so I may have good cheer.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: What, a feast, a feast?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I' faith, I thank him; he hath bid me to a calf's

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: head and a capon; the which if I do not carve most

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: curiously, say my knife's naught. Shall I not find

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: a woodcock too?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Sir, your wit ambles well; it goes easily.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I'll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit the

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: other day. I said, thou hadst a fine wit: 'True,'

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: said she, 'a fine little one.' 'No,' said I, 'a

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: great wit:' 'Right,' says she, 'a great gross one.'

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: 'Nay,' said I, 'a good wit:' 'Just,' said she, 'it

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: hurts nobody.' 'Nay,' said I, 'the gentleman

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: is wise:' 'Certain,' said she, 'a wise gentleman.'

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: 'Nay,' said I, 'he hath the tongues:' 'That I

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: believe,' said she, 'for he swore a thing to me on

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Monday night, which he forswore on Tuesday morning;

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: there's a double tongue; there's two tongues.' Thus

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: did she, an hour together, transshape thy particular

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: virtues: yet at last she concluded with a sigh, thou

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: wast the properest man in Italy.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: For the which she wept heartily and said she cared

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: not.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Yea, that she did: but yet, for all that, an if she

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: did not hate him deadly, she would love him dearly:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: the old man's daughter told us all.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: All, all; and, moreover, God saw him when he was

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: hid in the garden.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: But when shall we set the savage bull's horns on

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: the sensible Benedick's head?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Yea, and text underneath, 'Here dwells Benedick the

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: married man'?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Fare you well, boy: you know my mind. I will leave

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you now to your gossip-like humour: you break jests

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: as braggarts do their blades, which God be thanked,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: hurt not. My lord, for your many courtesies I thank

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you: I must discontinue your company: your brother

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the bastard is fled from Messina: you have among

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you killed a sweet and innocent lady. For my Lord

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Lackbeard there, he and I shall meet: and, till

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: then, peace be with him.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: He is in earnest.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: In most profound earnest; and, I'll warrant you, for

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: the love of Beatrice.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And hath challenged thee.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Most sincerely.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: doublet and hose and leaves off his wit!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape a

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: doctor to such a man.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: But, soft you, let me be: pluck up, my heart, and

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: be sad. Did he not say, my brother was fled?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Enter DOGBERRY, VERGES, and the Watch, with CONRADE and BORACHIO

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Come you, sir: if justice cannot tame you, she

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: shall ne'er weigh more reasons in her balance: nay,

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: an you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must be looked to.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: How now? two of my brother's men bound! Borachio

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: one!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Hearken after their offence, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Officers, what offence have these men done?

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Marry, sir, they have committed false report;

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: moreover, they have spoken untruths; secondarily,

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: they are slanders; sixth and lastly, they have

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified unjust

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: things; and, to conclude, they are lying knaves.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: First, I ask thee what they have done; thirdly, I

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: ask thee what's their offence; sixth and lastly, why

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: they are committed; and, to conclude, what you lay

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: to their charge.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Rightly reasoned, and in his own division: and, by

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: my troth, there's one meaning well suited.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Who have you offended, masters, that you are thus

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: bound to your answer? this learned constable is

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: too cunning to be understood: what's your offence?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Sweet prince, let me go no farther to mine answer:

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: do you hear me, and let this count kill me. I have

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: deceived even your very eyes: what your wisdoms

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: could not discover, these shallow fools have brought

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: to light: who in the night overheard me confessing

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: to this man how Don John your brother incensed me

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: to slander the Lady Hero, how you were brought into

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: the orchard and saw me court Margaret in Hero's

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: garments, how you disgraced her, when you should

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: marry her: my villany they have upon record; which

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: I had rather seal with my death than repeat over

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: to my shame. The lady is dead upon mine and my

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: master's false accusation; and, briefly, I desire

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: nothing but the reward of a villain.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Runs not this speech like iron through your blood?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I have drunk poison whiles he utter'd it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: But did my brother set thee on to this?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Yea, and paid me richly for the practise of it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: He is composed and framed of treachery:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And fled he is upon this villany.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Sweet Hero! now thy image doth appear

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: In the rare semblance that I loved it first.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Come, bring away the plaintiffs: by this time our

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: sexton hath reformed Signior Leonato of the matter:

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: and, masters, do not forget to specify, when time

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: and place shall serve, that I am an ass.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Here, here comes master Signior Leonato, and the

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Sexton too.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Re-enter LEONATO and ANTONIO, with the Sexton

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Which is the villain? let me see his eyes,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: That, when I note another man like him,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I may avoid him: which of these is he?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: If you would know your wronger, look on me.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast kill'd

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Mine innocent child?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Yea, even I alone.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: No, not so, villain; thou beliest thyself:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Here stand a pair of honourable men;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: A third is fled, that had a hand in it.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I thank you, princes, for my daughter's death:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Record it with your high and worthy deeds:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: 'Twas bravely done, if you bethink you of it.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I know not how to pray your patience;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Yet I must speak. Choose your revenge yourself;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Impose me to what penance your invention

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Can lay upon my sin: yet sinn'd I not

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: But in mistaking.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: By my soul, nor I:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And yet, to satisfy this good old man,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I would bend under any heavy weight

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: That he'll enjoin me to.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: That were impossible: but, I pray you both,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Possess the people in Messina here

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: How innocent she died; and if your love

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Can labour ought in sad invention,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And sing it to her bones, sing it to-night:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To-morrow morning come you to my house,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And since you could not be my son-in-law,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Be yet my nephew: my brother hath a daughter,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Almost the copy of my child that's dead,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And she alone is heir to both of us:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Give her the right you should have given her cousin,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And so dies my revenge.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: O noble sir,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Your over-kindness doth wring tears from me!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I do embrace your offer; and dispose

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: For henceforth of poor Claudio.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To-morrow then I will expect your coming;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To-night I take my leave. This naughty man

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Who I believe was pack'd in all this wrong,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Hired to it by your brother.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: No, by my soul, she was not,

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me,

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: But always hath been just and virtuous

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: In any thing that I do know by her.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Moreover, sir, which indeed is not under white and

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: black, this plaintiff here, the offender, did call

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: me ass: I beseech you, let it be remembered in his

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: punishment. And also, the watch heard them talk of

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: one Deformed: they say be wears a key in his ear and

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: a lock hanging by it, and borrows money in God's

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: name, the which he hath used so long and never paid

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: that now men grow hard-hearted and will lend nothing

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: for God's sake: pray you, examine him upon that point.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Your worship speaks like a most thankful and

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: reverend youth; and I praise God for you.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: There's for thy pains.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: God save the foundation!

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thank thee.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: I leave an arrant knave with your worship; which I

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: beseech your worship to correct yourself, for the

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: example of others. God keep your worship! I wish

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: your worship well; God restore you to health! I

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: humbly give you leave to depart; and if a merry

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: meeting may be wished, God prohibit it! Come, neighbour.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Exeunt DOGBERRY and VERGES

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Until to-morrow morning, lords, farewell.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Farewell, my lords: we look for you to-morrow.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: We will not fail.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: To-night I'll mourn with Hero.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: [To the Watch]  Bring you these fellows on. We'll

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: talk with Margaret,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Exeunt, severally
